newsitem.title: USA: Hubble spots rare cartwheel-shaped galaxy.
newsitem.headline: Hubble spots rare cartwheel-shaped galaxy.

text.p: Startling images from the Hubble Space Telescope of "comet-clouds" in a rare cartwheel-shaped galaxy could shed light on gyrations that may lie ahead for our own Milky Way, scientists said on Tuesday.

The comet-clouds are not really comets but have the distinctive streaming tails that comets possess, and are evidence of a massive galactic collision 200 million years ago, scientists at the Space Telescope Science Institute reported in a statement accompanying the pictures.
The images, made two years ago by the orbiting Hubble but released now after thorough analysis, show a starry wagon-wheel with wispy, almost invisible spokes and a dense, swirling, gaseous hub.
At the edge of the hub, or nucleus, white-headed comet-clouds appear to be chasing each other at speeds up to 700,000 miles (1.127 million km) an hour.

"It's a real rarity, an eye-grabber," Curt Struck, who analysed the images, said by telephone from Iowa State University, referring to the galaxy's distinctive shape, which has prompted astronomers to call it the Cartwheel Galaxy.
"Rings like that (the wheel's outer starry rim) are only produced when galaxies collide nearly head-on," Struck said. The wheel's evanescent spokes are further signs of such a cosmic smash-up.
Astronomers believe the Cartwheel collided with a smaller galaxy but that the two did not merge.
Struck said the smaller galaxy wound up about 100,000 light-years away -- a mere stone's throw in the cosmic context but vast by Earth standards.
A light-year is about 6 trillion miles (10 trillion km), the distance light travels in a year. The Cartwheel is 500 million light-years from Earth.

Another unique feature of the Cartwheel is the near-absence of young stars or star-forming regions in its interior, Struck said. The stars are almost exclusively located in the galaxy's circular perimeter.
By contrast, the Milky Way Galaxy, where Earth is located, has numerous areas where stars are born, and stars stud its entire two-armed swirling form.
The study of the Cartwheel is important, Struck said, because galactic evolution is generally caused by collisions: "When they're messed up a little by a collision, things are pushed along."
The collision appears to have formed the comet-clouds as well as the sparkling wheel, he said.
In the Milky Way, Struck believes that the Great Magellanic Clouds, visible in the southern sky, are evidence of a collision with a smaller galaxy, and future collisions are likely.
"We're in a group of galaxies and probably in the future we will interact with them," he said. "It's probably part of the story of our Milky Way."
